Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 12:59AM BikerBabe1 wrote:    This is what I posted last December before my procedure.  It might help.    I am also going to bump the thread on this topic from last year.  More ideas . . .    I am having the injections on the 20th.  After I read this thread, I thought I should call the Nuclear Medicine Department where I will have the SNB injection.  I am so glad I did. Very reassuring. They were great about detailing the procedure and addressing my fears about the pain.  The procedure at this hospital is to inject the lidocaine in first and then exchanging the syringe (leaving the needle in) they inject the SNB substance.  Leaving the needle in reduces the need for a second injection and apparently insures that when they inject the substance, they inject it exactly where the lidocaine has been dispersed.  The tech I talked to said that 95% of the patients don't feel the substance going in at all.  She said on rare occasions, the substance may go beyond where the lidocaine has spread and patients report feeling a brief burning sensation but nothing substantial.
Posts.Title: Why don't they offer tranquilizers on these types of biopsies? MaraSara debbie6122

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 08:01PM BikerBabe1 wrote: I had a stereotactic biopsy on November 9th. I did not have any pre-medication, although I would if I had to do it over again.  I did experience pain both when they put the local anesthetic in and when they placed the larger gauge needle for the biopsy. It was definitely uncomfortable. I think this had to do with where my calcifications were: they were very near the chest wall and deep.  Everyone was so nice and I one of the medical assistants standing near my head distracting me.  Afterwards, I was mostly stiff from having to be in one place for so long.  I wish you well with your biopsy.  Let us know how it goes.

Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 08:59PM BikerBabe1 wrote: I think this is an important discussion.  I don't have the answer but I do know that for me, it has been a fine line between acting on my gut based upon reasonable information vs. acting on my gut based on fear.   Here is my experience with the recommendation of waiting and coming to terms with whether my gut or my doctor's recommendations should prevail. In December 2010, I was diagnosed with DCIS and had a UMX.  I have had several  surgeries and in November had a follow up MRI.  The MRI showed a small (less than a cm) growth on my sternum, which apparently had been there at my last MRI the year before.  The Rad. Dr. ordered a follow-up CT but preliminarily stated that it looked like a benign hemangianoma.  Well, I went to the worst case scenario that it was some form of mets, researching and researching and initially believing that a biopsy would be the only solution that I would settle for.  The CT confirmed that it was the benign tumor given some very specific characteristics seen on the CT.  Because it had been stable for more than a year, both the rad. dr. and my onc recommended a follow up MRI in a year (which I would having regardless, for surveillance purposes).  At first I was like NO WAY, I want to definitively know by biopsy.  But eventually, I went with the doctors' recommendation.   What was most important for me in making this decision was, as Beesie stated, making sure that I was informed and that options were thoroughly evaluated in the context of my diagnosis.  I did my part by researching this type of tumor and being prepared with my questions when I met with the Onc. I brought my daughter along.  I also gave myself permission to seek a second opinion or third opinion if necessary if I was was uncomfortable with the oncs recommendation.  I know for some people, going to another doctor can be hard to do.  For me, sometimes I hesitate about this because I don't want to "hurt the doctor's feelings."  A good doctor will not have a problem with this and will sometimes encourage a second opinion. I was surprised that after all that, I was quite comfortable with the onc's recommendation given the following facts:  (1) my diagnosis was DCIS and not invasive, which, by definition, cannot metastasize; (2)  the lesion on the MRI had been stable over the last year; (3) the lesion on the MRI had the definitive characteristics of the benign tumor (which I had independently researched this) and (4) a biopsy of the sternum is not without risk and (5) there was no guarantee that with this size and type of growth, the biopsy would generate anything conclusive for purposes of diagnosis. Now, I know that only time will tell if this was the right decision for me but I have been able to proceed knowing that I made it with the best information available at the time.   This is not to say that a doctor who fails to follow the standard of care or respond reasonably to patient concerns and questions should not be held accountable. Nor is it in any way to imply that patients are to blame when they rely upon their doctor's recommendation and the doctor's recommendation turns out to have very serious consequences to the health of and prognosis for patient.   If a doctor makes a recommendation and a patient relies upon that recommendation to his or her detriment, the doctor should be held accountable.

Posts.Title: Feeling Woozy After Surgery from Tuesday ScariedCat ScariedCat

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 01:09PM BikerBabe1 wrote: Anniemomofthree:  I will be thinking of you today and tomorrow.  This morning I called the Nuclear Medicine Department where I will have the SNB injection.  I am so glad I did. Very reassuring. They were great about detailing the procedure and addressing my fears about the pain.  The procedure at this hospital (Swedish Hospital in Seattle) is to inject the lidocaine in first and then exchanging the syringe (leaving the needle in) they inject the SNB substance.  Leaving the needle in reduces the need for a second injection and apparently insures that when they inject the substance, they inject it exactly where the lidocaine has been dispersed.  The tech I talked to said that 95% of the patients don't feel the substance going in at all or very little pain.  She said on rare occasions, the substance may go beyond where the lidocaine has spread and patients report feeling a brief burning sensation.  She stated that patients reported that compared to the stereotactic biopsy, the injection was a piece of cake.  After reading through the thread regarding pain on the SNB injection  (which scared me), it seems that procedures vary from hospital to hospital--a small percentage of hospitals state that lidocaine may interfere with the SNB injections.  It would be important to find out whether the hospital uses lidocaine and if they don't, advocate that they address pain concerns.  On the SNB injection thread, several women mentioned studies that have concluded that lidocaine does not interfere with the SNB and have used them to advocate for the use of lidocaine for the injection process. While I feel at peace about my decision, I continue to take the anxiety about the surgery one day at a time.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 06:46PM BikerBabe1 wrote: OJulie67:  I don't wait well either.  For me, I always feel more in control if I make phone calls "checking in" to see if the results are in.  Normally, I manage to get the results a little sooner than they originally said they would be ready (I think they give themselves extra room when they predict how long it will be).   And my philosophy is that I always get more info with a little sugar than my normal grumpy attitude when I don't get what I want--my DH taught me that.  I feel like I am doing something and not just waiting for someone else.  I think sometimes I get the info sooner just so they can get me off their case.  I have been watching this thread and thinking about you.  I know how hard it is.
